com.ibm.lpex.alef
Class LpexAbstractTextEditor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.eclipse.ui.part.WorkbenchPart
        |
        +--com.ibm.lpex.alef.LpexEditorPart
              |
              +--com.ibm.lpex.alef.LpexAbstractTextEditor
Direct Known Subclasses:
LpexTextEditor
public abstract class LpexAbstractTextEditor
extends LpexEditorPart
implements com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditor, com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditorActionConstants, com.ibm.jface.text.IDocumentListener, com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.IElementStateListener

A line oriented, LPEX-based abstract default implementation of ITextEditor. It is the responsibility of the subclass to configure the editor appropriately.

Several AbstractTextEditor classes, methods, and fields are not available in LpexAbstractTextEditor. Most programming of the underlying LPEX widget should be done directly via its LpexView and LpexWindow.

  • the popup (context) menu is populated according to LPEX's popup parameter; action "Goto line" is not added - in LPEX one goes to a line easier from the command line (e.g., ":150" or, simpler, just "150")
  • protected String getLabelProposal(IDocument document, int start, int length)
    -- the method used during marker creation here is getLabelProposal(String text, int start)
  • protected ISelectionChangedListener getSelectionChangedListener(), public void markAsContentDependentAction(), public void markAsSelectionDependentAction(), protected void updateAction(), protected void updateContentDependentActions(), protected void updateSelectionDependentActions()
    -- the global (Workbench) actions are updated on every refresh on the LPEX screen.

See Also:
getLpexView(), getLpexWindow()

Method Detail

setDocumentProvider

public void setDocumentProvider(com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.IDocumentProvider provider)
Deprecated. since 01/22/2001 visibility will change to protected

Sets the editor's document provider. This method must be called before the editor's control is created.

IDocumentProvider is an interface used by the ITextEditor to interact with its input element based on the input element's textual representation as IDocument. A document provider may be shared between multiple editors.

Specified by:
setDocumentProvider in interface com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditor

createPartControl

public void createPartControl(com.ibm.swt.widgets.Composite parent)
Creates the SWT controls for a part. This is a multistep process:
  1. create one or more controls within the parent
  2. set the parent layout as needed
  3. hook focus on each of the controls - when focus is gained, notify all focus listeners
  4. register any global actions with the IActionService
  5. register any popup menus with the IActionService.
Other steps may be performed as required. 1.Register a selection provider with the ISelectionService.
Overrides:
createPartControl in class com.ibm.eclipse.ui.part.WorkbenchPart
See Also:
IWorkbenchPart.createPartControl(com.ibm.swt.widgets.Composite)

dispose

public void dispose()
Dispose this part and discard all part state. From this point on, the part will not be referenced within the workbench.

This method is called at the end of the part lifecycle: release any resources, fonts, images, etc. held by the part. The part control has already been disposed, so there is no need to dispose it here.

Overrides:
dispose in class com.ibm.eclipse.ui.part.WorkbenchPart
See Also:
IWorkbenchPart.dispose()

doSaveAs

public void doSaveAs()
Save the contents of the target to another object. If the save is successful, the editor should fire a property-changed event, reflecting the new dirty state and input object. The implementation of this method does nothing.
See Also:
IEditorPart.doSaveAs()

doSave

public void doSave()
Save the contents of the target. If the save is successful, the editor fires a property-changed event, reflecting the new dirty state.
See Also:
IEditorPart.doSave()

isSavePossible

public boolean isSavePossible()
Returns whether the textual presentation has been modified and thus a save operation could be performed.

What's returned by this method determines both the display, in the viewer label, of the dirty-indication '*' which follows the file name, and the enablement of the Save menu items (only enabled on changed documents in Eclipse).

Specified by:
isSavePossible in interface com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditor
See Also:
ITextEditor.isSavePossible()

createActions

protected void createActions()
Create the editor's standard actions, and connect the global actions with the corresponding workbench actions.

Actions handled in here are the global workbench actions and the context menu actions, including the standard editor actions defined in ITextOperationTarget. For LPEX's own contributions to the Eclipse context see LpexContextContributor.

getAdapter

public java.lang.Object getAdapter(java.lang.Class required)
Return the object which is an instance of the given class associated with this object, or null if no such object can be found.

IAdaptable - an interface for an adaptable object. Adaptable objects can be dynamically extended to provide different interfaces (or "adapters"). Adapters are created by adapter factories, which are in turn managed by type by adapter managers.

Overrides:
getAdapter in class com.ibm.eclipse.ui.part.WorkbenchPart
See Also:
IAdaptable.getAdapter(Class)

getLabelProposal

protected java.lang.String getLabelProposal(java.lang.String text,
                                            int start)
Propose the label for a marker being initialized. Called by initializeMarker(). A String delimited by white space is extracted from the specified text.

The implementation in here is more liberal than AbstractTextEditor's in striving to find some relevant text for a label proposal.

Parameters:
text - current token at cursor / text of the current line / the current selection
start - ONE-based starting index for extracting the label proposal
See Also:
initializeMarker(com.ibm.eclipse.core.resources.IMarker)

initializeMarker

public void initializeMarker(com.ibm.eclipse.core.resources.IMarker marker)
Initialize the given marker (e.g., an IMarker.BOOKMARK just created) with the current cursor position or text selection in the editor's LpexSourceViewer.

If there is no text selection in this view, the cursor position will be set in the marker, and the token or word at the cursor will be used for the label proposal. If a block has been selected, the selection will be used for the marker; if the cursor is located at the start or end of this block, then it's assumed the text has just been selected for the purpose of creating the marker, and the selection text will be used as a preliminary proposal for the marker label.

Specified by:
initializeMarker in interface com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditor
See Also:
getLabelProposal(java.lang.String, int), AddMarkerAction.initializeMarker(com.ibm.eclipse.core.resources.IMarker)

gotoLine

public void gotoLine(int lineNumber)
Place the cursor at the start of the given document line, and reveal it.

Preferred method: 

    LpexView lpexView = getLpexView();
    if (lpexView != null) {
       lpexView.doCommand("locate line " + lineNumber);
       lpexView.triggerAction(lpexView.actionId("textWindow"));
       }
Specified by:
gotoLine in interface com.ibm.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditor
See Also:
ITextEditor.gotoLine(int)

updateMarkers

public void updateMarkers()
Bring the location of this editor's MarkerManager markers back in sync with the location of LpexView's corresponding marks.

As LPEX doesn't keep the IDocument and consequently its listeneres up-to-date, during an edit session the up-to-date location of a marker can only be established from the corresponding LPEX mark set in LpexView. This positional update of the markers managed by the marker manager takes place on every save operation.
